messageBody:
On 2008-08-27 John Cowan wrote:
> > particularly the differences between the UK
> > accents and the American
> > > accents. (eg: the caught/cot merger in
> > > General American).
>
> That's just something Americans (actually, only
> about 50% of them) will have to learn, just as
> most anglophones will have to learn when to
> write 18 Way and when to write 20 Why, because
> they no longer distinguish them in speech. (The
> distinction is still robust in Scotland,
> Ireland, and the American South.)
>
>

(Sorry for coming in late -- the old phenomenon of
hitting "Save" instead of "Send" struck again"...)

I've long felt that any reformed spelling system
for English with international intentions should
simply disregard to distinguish TRAP-BATH-
PALM/FATHER, LOT-CLOTH-THOUGHT and NORTH-FORCE
respectively. For the writer this simply means
that these sounds are spelled the same, except
that to the General American speaker some words --
the PALM/FATHER words -- with ought to be spelled
with the LOT-CLOTH-THOUGHT sign will be spelled
with the TRAP-BATH-PALM/FATHER sign. It would
perhaps tax the reader a bit more, but certainly
not more than Orthodox does.

For Quickscript this would mean that Ah and Awe
will normally only be used before Roe, except for
unnativized foreign names where these letters
should be used to indicate vowels of the [a]-[A]
and [o]-[O] types respectively.

One might argue that for a GA speaker to learn to
distinguish TRAP-PALM/FATHER is akin to a General
British speaker having to learn where to put R.
However the problem of how to spell BATH and CLOTH
is unsolvable short of inventing new signs for
these sets only, which would probably not be
possible WRT QS. There is the added problem that
even though BATH and CLOTH words are usually
characterized by one of the four fricatives /f, T,
D/ (Fee Thaw They) and /s/ or by one of the four
nasal-initiated clusters /nd, nt, ns/ and /nS/ (No-
She) following the vowel GB has many more words
with the TRAP vowel before these sounds, so that
no clear rule for the translation from Orthodox to
QS, or from GA to GB, can be given.

/BP 8^)>
--
Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch atte melroch dotte se

"C'est en vain que nos Josués littéraires crient
à la langue de s'arrêter; les langues ni le soleil
ne s'arrêtent plus. Le jour où elles se *fixent*,
c'est qu'elles meurent." (Victor Hugo)
